intro: Haplopappus mieresii, commonly known as the Mieres' pappus, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of western North America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and papery bracts. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its small, yellow flowers bloom in the spring, and it produces fluffy seeds that are dispersed by the wind. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
